articles.headline: A Year of Highs and Corrections in the Art Market
articles.snippet: Modern art roared on while old masters and young stars lost value.
articles.abstract: Modern art roared on while old masters and young stars lost value.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Looking back at the headlines, 2015 was a momentous year for the art market.

articles.headline: Think Seriously About Spending for Play
articles.snippet: Deliberate planning for leisure, concentrating on activities that refresh and reinvigorate, may actually mean more fun for less money.
articles.abstract: Deliberate planning for leisure, concentrating on activities that refresh and reinvigorate, may actually mean more fun for less money.
articles.lead_paragraph: Maybe you keep a budget. If you do, perhaps you have entries for travel or even specific entries for your hobbies.

articles.headline: App Makers Reach Out to the Teenager on Mobile
articles.snippet: One app’s effort to understand its teenage audience illuminates the habits of a generation that is constantly connected and often anxious.
articles.abstract: One app’s effort to understand its teenage audience illuminates the habits of a generation that is constantly connected and often anxious.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the past decade, advertisers have spent untold millions trying to turn Talia Kocar and her peers in the millennial generation into loyal customers. But on a recent afternoon in Santa Monica, Calif., in a kind of consumer torch-passing, Ms. Kocar, 25, watched a focus group of teenagers drink free Snapple and suck Doritos powder off their thumbs while answering questions about their smartphones.

articles.headline: At C.D.C., a Debate Behind Recommendations on Cellphone Risk
articles.snippet: While consensus holds that there is little to no evidence linking cellphone use to an increased risk of health problems, scientists and health agencies disagree about what guidance to give the public.
articles.abstract: While consensus holds that there is little to no evidence linking cellphone use to an increased risk of health problems, scientists and health agencies disagree about what guidance to give the public.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention published new guidelines 18 months ago regarding the radiation risk from cellphones, it used unusually bold language on the topic for the American health agency: “We recommend caution in cellphone use.”

articles.headline: Looking Beyond the Internet of Things
articles.snippet: Adam Bosworth, a tech pioneer, sees the future in servers that manage and learn from data gathered by sensors implanted in practically everything.
articles.abstract: Adam Bosworth, a tech pioneer, sees the future in servers that manage and learn from data gathered by sensors implanted in practically everything.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — If you have sent email on Google or used Microsoft’s browser or databases, you have touched the technology handiwork of Adam Bosworth.

articles.headline: Jihadists Deepen Collaboration in North Africa
articles.snippet: The active coordination is turning one of the most inhospitable territories on earth into a complex security challenge for African and global forces.
articles.abstract: The active coordination is turning one of the most inhospitable territories on earth into a complex security challenge for African and global forces.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAHARA DESERT, Niger — A group of light armored vehicles skated over the moonscape of the Sahara, part of one of the largest detachments the French military has deployed here since colonial times. Its mission is growing ever more urgent: to cut smuggling routes used by jihadists who have turned this inhospitable terrain into a sprawling security challenge for African and international forces alike.

articles.headline: Over 50, Female and Jobless Even as Others Return to Work
articles.snippet: Although the economy has improved since the financial crisis, waves from the recession continue to upend job seekers and now a new study shows long-term unemployment has risen among women.
articles.abstract: Although the economy has improved since the financial crisis, waves from the recession continue to upend job seekers and now a new study shows long-term unemployment has risen among women.
articles.lead_paragraph: The latest signs of an improving economy were good enough to help persuade the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates for the first time in nearly a decade. But the better job market is not good enough to land Chettie McAfee a job.

articles.headline: 5 Years and $7 Later, U.S. Returns a Seized Hip-Hop Site
articles.snippet: The blog OnSmash was among music sites shut down in 2010, accused of copyright infringement and selling counterfeit goods.
articles.abstract: The blog OnSmash was among music sites shut down in 2010, accused of copyright infringement and selling counterfeit goods.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the early hours of Thanksgiving Day in 2010, all the music at OnSmash.com, a popular hip-hop blog, disappeared. In place of its usual feed of videos, song links and industry gossip, the site displayed a seizure notice from the federal government, a result of a raid of dozens of websites suspected of trafficking in counterfeit goods and pirated content.

articles.headline: Iranian Protesters Ransack Saudi Embassy After Execution of Shiite Cleric
articles.snippet: The execution of Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr, an outspoken campaigner for Shiite rights, is likely to exacerbate sectarian tensions across the Middle East.
articles.abstract: The execution of Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr, an outspoken campaigner for Shiite rights, is likely to exacerbate sectarian tensions across the Middle East.
articles.lead_paragraph: Iranian protesters ransacked and set fire to the Saudi Embassy in Tehran on Saturday after Saudi Arabia executed an outspoken Shiite cleric who had criticized the kingdom’s treatment of its Shiite minority.

articles.headline: F.D.A. Regulator, Widowed by Cancer, Helps Speed Drug Approval
articles.snippet: Dr. Richard Pazdur, the Food and Drug Administration’s oncology chief, says his wife’s ordeal was influential in a change that many had advocated but that critics say erodes safeguards.
articles.abstract: Dr. Richard Pazdur, the Food and Drug Administration’s oncology chief, says his wife’s ordeal was influential in a change that many had advocated but that critics say erodes safeguards.
articles.lead_paragraph: BETHESDA, Md. — Mary Pazdur had exhausted the usual drugs for ovarian cancer, and with her tumors growing and her condition deteriorating, her last hope seemed to be an experimental compound that had yet to be approved by federal regulators.

articles.headline: For Donald Trump, Lessons From a Brother’s Suffering
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump, whose appeal is predicated on an aura of toughness and perpetual success, seldom speaks of his brother Freddy, who died as an alcoholic in 1981 at age 43.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump, whose appeal is predicated on an aura of toughness and perpetual success, seldom speaks of his brother Freddy, who died as an alcoholic in 1981 at age 43.
articles.lead_paragraph: One evening in the 1960s, Donald J. Trump, still in college but eager to make it big, met his older brother, Freddy, for dinner in a Queens apartment complex built by their father.

articles.headline: Electrifying India, With the Sun and Small Loans
articles.snippet: A generation of Indian energy entrepreneurs is out to prove that a fast, clean and economical route to universal electrification is through solar home systems, financed with small bank loans.
articles.abstract: A generation of Indian energy entrepreneurs is out to prove that a fast, clean and economical route to universal electrification is through solar home systems, financed with small bank loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few years ago, the hundred or so residents of Paradeshappanamatha, a secluded hamlet in the southern Indian state of Karnataka, gathered along the central pathway between their 22 densely clustered homes, and watched as government workers hoisted a solar-powered streetlamp. As the first display of electricity in the town, it was an object of mild interest, but, being outside, the light didn’t help anyone cook or study, and only attracted moths.

articles.headline: FASB Proposes to Curb What Companies Must Disclose
articles.snippet: A regulatory change that would allow companies more discretion in deciding what is “material” information arouses concern among investors and auditors.
articles.abstract: A regulatory change that would allow companies more discretion in deciding what is “material” information arouses concern among investors and auditors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Accounting rule makers are not generally known as flame-throwers. But with a new proposal, the Financial Accounting Standards Board has lobbed a miniature Molotov cocktail into the usually staid world of audit standards, upsetting investor groups and experts in the field.

articles.headline: On Perilous Migrant Trail, Women Often Become Prey to Sexual Abuse
articles.snippet: Along with all the perils refugees face, women have added accounts of being assaulted, traumas that do not end with their arrival in Europe.
articles.abstract: Along with all the perils refugees face, women have added accounts of being assaulted, traumas that do not end with their arrival in Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — One Syrian woman who joined the stream of migrants to Germany was forced to pay down her husband’s debt to smugglers by making herself available for sex along the way. Another was beaten unconscious by a Hungarian prison guard after refusing his advances.

articles.headline: Sheldon Adelson’s Purchase of Las Vegas Paper Seen as a Power Play
articles.snippet: The billionaire casino magnate's recent purchase of The Las Vegas Review-Journal has prompted concerns that he could use the newspaper to influence a lawsuit against his business empire.
articles.abstract: The billionaire casino magnate's recent purchase of The Las Vegas Review-Journal has prompted concerns that he could use the newspaper to influence a lawsuit against his business empire.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Two days after Sheldon Adelson’s lawyers lost in their attempts to have a judge removed from a contentious lawsuit that threatens his gambling empire, a call went out to the publisher of this city’s most prominent newspaper.
articles.byline: By Ravi Somaiya, Ian Lovett and Barry Meier

articles.headline: Uber’s No-Holds-Barred Expansion Strategy Fizzles in Germany
articles.snippet: The ride-hailing company has retreated from several German cities. Its withdrawal from Frankfurt offers a case study of what went wrong.
articles.abstract: The ride-hailing company has retreated from several German cities. Its withdrawal from Frankfurt offers a case study of what went wrong.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Uber is rapidly expanding its ride-hailing operations across the globe. But here in this city of 690,000 — less than the population of San Francisco, Uber’s hometown — the company recently did something unusual: It retreated.

articles.headline: Many See I.R.S. Penalties as More Affordable Than Insurance
articles.snippet: Expensive premiums and high deductibles for policies sold under the Affordable Care Act make tax penalties the preferred option for some resisters.
articles.abstract: Expensive premiums and high deductibles for policies sold under the Affordable Care Act make tax penalties the preferred option for some resisters.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Clint Murphy let the deadline for getting health insurance by the new year pass without a second thought.

articles.headline: Saudi Arabia Cuts Ties With Iran Amid Fallout From Cleric’s Execution
articles.snippet: Saudi Arabia gave Iranian diplomats 48 hours to leave the kingdom as the two powers exchanged heated words after the Saudis executed a prominent Shiite cleric.
articles.abstract: Saudi Arabia gave Iranian diplomats 48 hours to leave the kingdom as the two powers exchanged heated words after the Saudis executed a prominent Shiite cleric.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Saudi Arabia cut diplomatic ties with Iran on Sunday and gave Iranian diplomats 48 hours to leave the kingdom, marking a swift escalation in a strategic and sectarian rivalry that underpins conflicts across the Middle East.

articles.headline: Bernie Sanders, Needing Early Lift, Builds Iowa Ground Operation
articles.snippet: His campaign has assembled an extensive effort for the crucial Feb. 1 caucuses, with 100 paid staff members and volunteer leaders.
articles.abstract: His campaign has assembled an extensive effort for the crucial Feb. 1 caucuses, with 100 paid staff members and volunteer leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — This fall the words of a Hillary Clinton backer were posted like a locker-room taunt on the wall at Bernie Sanders’s Iowa headquarters: “There is no Sanders organization.”
articles.byline: By Trip Gabriel and Amy Chozick

articles.headline: A Standout Year for Deals, in Volume and Complexity
articles.snippet: Last year generated $4.7 trillion in announced deals, but it was also characterized by dozens of complex and creative financial structures.
articles.abstract: Last year generated $4.7 trillion in announced deals, but it was also characterized by dozens of complex and creative financial structures.
articles.lead_paragraph: Of all the ways to describe mergers and acquisitions in 2015, “plain vanilla” is not one of them.

articles.headline: Armed Group Vows to Continue Occupation at Oregon Refuge
articles.snippet: The occupiers are protesting the government’s treatment of two ranchers ordered to report again to prison for arsons in 2001 and 2006.
articles.abstract: The occupiers are protesting the government’s treatment of two ranchers ordered to report again to prison for arsons in 2001 and 2006.
articles.lead_paragraph: BURNS, Ore. — The protesters arrived in this old lumber town to support a 73-year-old rancher and his son who had been sentenced to prison for setting fires that spread to federal lands. It was billed as a peaceful demonstration, but after “Amazing Grace” was sung and hugs were exchanged, a small, armed contingent declared outside a supermarket that it was taking a stand and asked who wanted to join.
articles.byline: By Kirk Johnson and Jack Healy

articles.headline: State Focus and Infusion of Funding Buoy Gun Control Advocates
articles.snippet: With tens of millions of dollars in contributions to spend, groups are looking to toughen state and local measures in ways that the Republican-led Congress has rejected on the federal level.
articles.abstract: With tens of millions of dollars in contributions to spend, groups are looking to toughen state and local measures in ways that the Republican-led Congress has rejected on the federal level.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALEXANDRIA, Va. — With President Obama poised to act on his own authority to try to stem gun violence, his gun control allies are using big-money donors and shifting tactics to try to remake the political landscape in the national gun debate, challenging and sometimes even besting the powerful National Rifle Association in state-by-state battles.

articles.headline: Under New Leader, Discovery Channel’s Brand Reboot Shows Promise
articles.snippet: By moving away from ratings stunts and tired content, Rich Ross has managed to help lift the TV network’s viewership and nab a sought-after demographic.
articles.abstract: By moving away from ratings stunts and tired content, Rich Ross has managed to help lift the TV network’s viewership and nab a sought-after demographic.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood loves a comeback story. And right now, there is perhaps none better than Rich Ross and Discovery.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and John Koblin

articles.headline: Raine Group Finds Deals for Clients, and Itself
articles.snippet: Quiet, huge transactions include selling a $400 million stake in Manchester City soccer team’s parent to China Media.
articles.abstract: Quiet, huge transactions include selling a $400 million stake in Manchester City soccer team’s parent to China Media.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Raine Group may not be as instantly recognizable as Wall Street fixtures like Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Economists Take Aim at Wealth Inequality
articles.snippet: At the American Economic Association’s annual meeting, what was once mainly an issue among players on the margins of the profession is taking center stage.
articles.abstract: At the American Economic Association’s annual meeting, what was once mainly an issue among players on the margins of the profession is taking center stage.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When pundits and presidential candidates talk about inequality and the tiny sliver of the population whose fortunes have soared, they often drop names like Warren Buffett, Bill Gates, Sheldon Adelson and Mark Zuckerberg.

articles.headline: Wall St. Slides After Chinese Stocks Plunge
articles.snippet: Weak manufacturing data for China and worries about the depreciation of the renminbi pushed stocks in the United States and Europe sharply lower.
articles.abstract: Weak manufacturing data for China and worries about the depreciation of the renminbi pushed stocks in the United States and Europe sharply lower.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the first trading day of the new year, investors’ old worries flooded back.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Paul Mozur

articles.headline: If the I.R.S. Is Watching You, You’ll Pay Up
articles.snippet: New research into tax cheating aims to answer the question of what will get people to pay their taxes. The answer, emphatically, is to check on them.
articles.abstract: New research into tax cheating aims to answer the question of what will get people to pay their taxes. The answer, emphatically, is to check on them.
articles.lead_paragraph: What would be more likely to get you to report the whole truth and nothing but the truth on your tax returns? A notice that says “Don’t cheat” or one that says “Don’t be a cheater”?

articles.headline: Takata Emails Show Brash Exchanges About Data Tampering
articles.snippet: The documents, unsealed as part of a lawsuit, show discussions about dressing up data at the airbag supplier, which is under fire for defective devices.
articles.abstract: The documents, unsealed as part of a lawsuit, show discussions about dressing up data at the airbag supplier, which is under fire for defective devices.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Honda Motor Company said two months ago that it would no longer use Takata as supplier of its airbags, the automaker said that testing data on the airbags had been “misrepresented and manipulated.”
articles.byline: By Danielle Ivory and Hiroko Tabuchi

articles.headline: General Motors, Gazing at Future, Invests $500 Million in Lyft
articles.snippet: Beyond the financial backing, the carmaker will develop an autonomous on-demand network of self-driving cars.
articles.abstract: Beyond the financial backing, the carmaker will develop an autonomous on-demand network of self-driving cars.
articles.lead_paragraph: The founders of Lyft, the ride-hailing service, have long imagined that the future of transportation would involve fewer cars on the road. Now General Motors is helping the start-up reach that goal.
